reviewText: New York Mysteries: Secrets of the Mafia is a really great Hidden Object Game. The story is compelling: you're a detctive  in 1950s NYC trying to solve a string of disappearances of Mafia bosses under mysterious circumstances. In addition, each of these disappearances seem related to another dissapearance, this time of a small child. Somehow butterflies are also related. It's a nice little mystery.\n\nThe puzzles are challenging, and there are several difficulty options you can choose from, affecting the amount of help the game gives in the form of visual cues or hints. The music's really cool and fits the theme nicely. I love the retro style and the period feel" of the 50s and the artwork really showcases that. Overall
date: New York Mysteries is a high-quality HOG.\n\nThere are loads of collectible items (and completing each collection earns you Steam achievements) and there are a lot of different areas to visit in the game. The map is huge
hoursPlayed: there is also a convenient fast-travel system allowing you to jump around from place to place quickly.\n\nOne thing you won't find in this HOG are word-lists and cluttered scenes where you have to cross all the words off the list by finding the items. Hidden object scenes are more organic here
voteText: you're given a group of silouettes and you have to work out the objects that fill them. Each of the objects is usually used in the scene to uncover one or more of the additional objects
helpfulPercent: so the scenes work out more like a puzzle than a straight-up search.\n\nThis seems like it is one of the longer HOGs I think I've played
votesHelpful: though it's still a game you can complete pretty quickly. I don't really see that as a down side at all though
votesTotal:
since the polished and well-presented gameplay and story are really enjoyable.

Here is some gameplay video footage of New York Mysteries: Secrets of the Mafia (shot by seph.au from Gaming All the Time):
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CoDH9mcap3c
Note: A copy of this game was provided for review purposes."

reviewText:
AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below)

Game Name: New York Mysteries: Secrets of the Mafia
Original Release: 2014
Genre Tags: Point & Click; Adventure; Hidden Object; Casual
My Overall Grade: B
Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 5-7 hours
Multiplayer Aspect: None
Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Casual gamers
REVIEWI play a lot of hidden-object/point-and-click adventure games because sometimes I just want a relaxing gaming experience where I have to think, but I don’t have to react.  Nevertheless, I will be the first to admit that: even when these games are well developed, I can understand why a large percentage of gamers would find them unexciting.   New York Mysteries: Secrets of the Mafia (Collector’s Edition) is one of the better hidden-object/point-and-click adventure games I have played, simply because there are so many things done “right.”  But if you don’t really like these types of games, you probably shouldn’t bother with it, because there isn’t anything special about it that will change your mind. However, any gamer who already enjoys this particular genre should definitely check this out.

All of the things you would want a game like this to have, it does have.  Various difficulties, a fast travel map, challenging-yet-intuitive puzzle solutions, collectibles, and achievements.  It also has a decent story and the cut-scenes aren’t horridly cringe-worthy, which many games in this genre can’t truly claim.  Another rare and awesome feature is the fact you can unlock most of the missable achievements from the “extras” menu to replay specific puzzles— rather than having to replay the entire game for one achievement.

One of the best features of the game, though, is the integrated strategy guide.  I think it is a great dynamic and it is certainly easier to use than having to alt-tab to find a guide online.  It is organized so that you can choose to use it: only to help find collectibles, only if you are stuck, the whole way through, or not at all.

New York Mysteries: Secrets of the Mafia (Collector’s Edition) certainly won’t be blowing anyone’s socks off, and it probably won’t appeal to gamers who aren’t big fans of the hidden-object/point-and-click adventure games.  But if you are a fan of this type of game, then I can wholeheartedly recommend this game to you, because it is definitely one of the better games in the genre.

Follow my curation page to see more of my recommendations!

reviewText:
As many of you may be aware, I'm a HOG addict at this point. I won't lie; I love this genre. I love puzzles, I love revealing stories step by step, and I love spending some mindless time on them. Yet, the HOG genre consists of one of the most repetitive gameplays ever. Thus, it is remarkably hard to make anything either new, or even refreshing as a HOG. New York Mysteries: Secrets of the Mafia is one great HOG, with hours of gameplay, imaginative puzzles that I haven't seen before which comes with comparatively logical item combination. Plus, the story is interesting!

It's New York, 1955. The fearsome Mafioso of their time disappear one by one, leaving only an odd green residue and a butterfly behind them. It is also reported that children all over the city disappear alongside these dangerous criminals, drawing the exact same butterfly as the last thing they do. Our protagonist, investigator and reporter Laura James is contacted by the curator of the New York Museum, where the last disappearance has occurred. Laura is asked to investigate this odd phenomenon and find the missing children if possible. She suddenly finds herself in a picture with a secret organization, old underground passages that trace all over the city and an Indian ghost story. How come all these odd happenings are connected?

Coming up with a strong and interesting story, this is a great game for its genre. Art and environment design are high quality - depicting the hidden beauty of New York City during its shadier years - , with beautiful character design and marvelous cinematics. There is real labor put into this game, I tell you. Voice acting isn't excellent, but it's obviously beyond par. I'm a bit disappointed that we don't hear Laura's voice commenting on something, but it's not a priority.

HOG scenes are not your usual. They are compact; weaved with puzzles and item combinations similar as an adventure game within themselves, designed to reach a singular item at the end. Puzzles are numerous and mostly brain scratching, designed elaborately. I went for not skipping any puzzle for the achievement, so it was a tough and fun experience for me. If you are into puzzle solving, this is a neat addition.

Maybe the greatest bonus of the game is its game time. Added up with the time you'll be spending for many imaginative puzzles and the bonus chapter, there is an approximate game time of 6-7 hours! The gameplay has an usual amount of backtracking, but with the usage of the interactive map, nothing's a chore. You are also given the option of collecting some phantom objects and collection items for achievements, if you are into that sort of thing.

If you are fresh out of HOGs to play, do not think twice. New York Mysteries: Secrets of the Mafia is an A+ HOG for you to enjoy. The game comes from FIVE-BN games, - nope, it's not Artifex Mundi, but definitely AM quality - a relatively small producer that I suggest keeping an eye on in the future. Enjoy!

Please also check out Lady Storyteller's Curator page here - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

reviewText:
Short version: 89%New York Mysteries is a great casual adventure game with a wide variety of puzzles and a surprisingly good plot. Don’t expect any traditional list-based hidden object scenes in it though.

Long version:New York Mysteries: Secrets of the Mafia is an ambitious game that tries to push the boundaries of the hidden object genre, but it doesn’t try to change too much.

Like many good HOGs, New York Mysteries knows the importance of a good story: we are following an investigative journalist on the trail of some mysterious child disappearances that always occur at the same time when a prominent member of the Mafia goes missing. While the plot involves a secret society and some supernatural elements, it retains the more realistic thriller-like atmosphere to the end.

Although it is classified as a HOG, the game has no traditional hidden object scenes, only procedural ones, where you have to use uncovered objects to get even more items. The developers focused on the numerous and diverse puzzles instead, including several types that are rarely seen in these kinds of games, elevating New York Mysteries among the best HOG types on Steam.

reviewText:
New York Mysteries: Secrets of the Mafia is one of the better hidden-oject games out there,if not one of the best.
Of course you have to solve various hidden object scenes, but there are more varied puzzles to be solved here, e.g. combine objects, solve memory style settings and other things.
The overall setting feels very retro, kinda like a noir-detective movie, which is very nice. Has a lot of attention to detail in the settings. Really good! The musical score fits the game perfect.
You can also achieve some Steam Achievements and get Trading Cards for Steam.Thumbs up!
Recommended for all hidden-object / adventure gamers.Way to go!

reviewText:
I'm a fan of the noir genre, and I've played many HOGs over the years - so I was very surprised to find this one that combines both features; it was a very fun and charming experience!

The main story features a journalist named Laura, who takes it upon herself to try and solve the mystery behind the kidnapped children and some mafia bosses who have been disappearing from all over New York City.

The main story features elements that are borrowed from the typical noir settings, as well as some paranormal traits, and it also borrows from some Native American folklore, as well.
It's very unique and enjoyable because it has pieces of the HOG and noir comfort zone, but the developers weren't too afraid to step beyond the borders to keep things fresh and unpredictable.

After completing the main storyline, a 'mini-episode' will be unlocked and players can enjoy going just a bit further into New York Mysteries' universe; via an underground city that has been left untouched for years.
But, when one of Laura's previous aquaintances has been poisoned by a mysterious toxin from an unknown plant, it's up to her to explore the abandoned city to try and find the antidote to save them.

As for gameplay, it's a mixture of HOG features as well as some from classic Point & Click adventure games.

It was nice to find and pick objects from a 'clean' scene instead of looking for them in a jumbled mess, like most typical HOGs have players do to progress. And, on the flipside, I enjoyed interacting with the enviroment, turning keys to open doors, mixing chemicals, rejoining torn papers as well as clicking on puzzle pieces.

On top of that, there's some nice cutscenes, along with some voice-acting (Though, sadly, Laura doesn't have much of a speaking part) to really paint a picture for new players.

It's a good balance, there's something for everyone to enjoy.

Now, with all that in mind, I will definitely say that the game was most definitely enjoyable from my end and was worth every penny - six hours for a comfortable playthrough for six bucks sounds fair to me; and with the replay value of revisiting the puzzles and the massive open-world levels with lush artwork, it's almost a steal!

However, that doesn't necessarily mean that it doesn't have some issues, however minor...

-You only have ONE save file, you can't have multiples.
Also, even worse, if you're replaying some of the main game again but want to also replay the bonus chapter, the save data for the bonus chapter WILL overwrite your save data for the main game - and vice versa.

-Spilling text on certain documents.
On some of the books and journal entries, the bottom of the text runs off of the page.
This can prove to be frustrating, I'd like to finish what I'm reading instead of it running off into oblivion or cutting abruptly.

-Bonus chapter's too short.
I can understand that it's a 'mini-episode' and all, but it just felt like the very end was a bit sudden; Laura explores the underground city and rescues her companion, but, there was no real explanation for what happened to the people there.
Maybe it's supposed to be left up for interpretation, but there could've been a little more to it.

Other than that, I loved playing through the game; it was nice to sit down and relax with.

reviewText:
I originally gave this game a very negative review. I was about half way through and the hint button broke, leaving me stuck with the developer's unsolvable, counter-intuitive puzzles. I think this happens when you complete the challenges in a sequence that the hint button doesn't expect. I went as far as asking for a refund from the seller. However, I withdrew my claim and review after I used a guide to get a bit further and then the hint button started working again.

The puzzles are impossible but the point and click parts are solid. Beware of the bugs, it isn't well-made and should've been patched months ago, the developers have been made aware of the problems but they just don't care. Overall, the atmosphere and story won me over and I can say that this is a good game but it has a lot of problems.

EDIT: Reverted to a negative review after yet another glitch left me unable to progress in my second playthrough. I half completed the minigame with the five circles at the start of chapter two, messed it up and couldn't reset it for some reason (seriously, why not?) so I put it down and wanted to pick it up again, thinking maybe that would reset it - it didn't, it just wouldn't let me pick it up again. This game is far more grief than it's worth.

reviewText:
As a life long New Yorker, I'm giving New York Mysteries: Secrets of the Mafia my seal of approval!

At first I thought this game was going to a full on historical piece traveling through old time New York, instead the game takes you on a bit of a goose chase after ghosts and mafia bosses. The game had less New York than I was expecting but still managed to be a fun experience. The game dances between mystery and sci fi, which can be annoying, however everything comes together smoothly.

You play Laura, a beautiful dame tasked with finding out why big bosses in the mafia have been disappearing and also why children have gone missing as well. With the help of Lucas and your detective skills, you travel via a series of underground tunnels to different points of interesting to piece together answers you seek.

Game play is solid, the mini games offer a great challenge as so the hidden object scenes. The scenes aren't your tradition flare, they are the type where you have to find items to then use on other items until you find the one item you're looking for. A hybrid of hidden item game and puzzle. These aren't my favorite, especially when that's all there is in the game, but they were fun so I didn't mind.

The game also offers a nice sound track as well as a strategy guide built in if you are ever stuck, this also makes getting the achievements a lot easier. The game is an all around great experience and despite a few flaws I found it very relaxing but also engaging. For a price tag of only seven dollars it offers hours of fun.

reviewText:
Another hidden object/puzzle game. Well made with fun puzzles, let down by contrived scenarios and silly plot.

7/10

Pros:
+ Can quickly jump to any location from the map menu, with an option to show which locations require an action.
+ Unusual hidden object game where instead of being given a text description of an object, you are given silhouette outlines instead. You need to use object X on location Y to uncover a new object.
+ Fun, varied puzzles (also skippable)
+ Decent animated cutscenes

Cons:
- Hard to take the plot seriously
- Really dated lip animations. Also one key NPC looks like he is levitating above his armchair
- Puzzles are very contrived

reviewText:
A fun and well designed adventure game. The game as a whole doesnt have much hidden objects per se. It does have a few of them but its mostly find this piece to complete this object. Example find a razor and find a pillow and cut open pillow to get next object. These are done well for the most part. The puzzles are a mix of old and new. A few I have never played and some that I have played a million times before in other games. So thats a mixed bag if you have played a lot of HOgames in the past.

Graphics are very well done and are super easy on the eyes. Great color and nice full motion scenes and voices. Really nicely done. The story is another standout. The focus is on mafia bosses and finding lost kids. Its well done and interesting.  Now for a minor nit pit. This game forces you to write stuff down as their are a lot of click the six objects and see what does what and in what order. I wish it would have the paper in upper right corner all the time for these type of super clickey puzzles. Its written in your book but its sometimes very inconvienant to go back and forth all the time.

The game does have some back tracking but thanks to the great map feature its doubtful you will get lost in the game. This is a very good game and its loads of fun. I recommend this one a lot. I am having a good time with this game.

reviewText:
Easy, casual adventure and Hidden Object game.

This game focuses more on collecting objects to reach new areas and has very few Hidden Object scenes and puzzles. The HO scenes require little effort as there are few items in scene besides the one your looking for. The story element is also easy as you have a limited inventory and so only few logical choices. Only a few logic puzzles which aren't taxing. The graphics and sound are okay. The story is again okay. It has a teleport map and in game walk through included. The achievements are easy enough to 100%.

Overall I would give this an okay. Good for crayon eaters.

reviewText: Despite the name, Secrets of the Mafia" is not really a gangster-themed tale.  The mafia is present merely as a plot device.  The themes of this HOG are more typical of the genre; mysticism
voteText: all of it set in a world where everyone uses elaborate puzzle locks to close everything
votesHelpful: and then carelessly scatters essential parts of those locks around the neighbourhood.\n\nA particular innovation in "New York Mysteries: Secrets of the Mafia" that I had never previously encountered is that the HO segments don't simply present you with a purposeless laundry list of items to find (and then
commentsCount: each item in your list (given in silhouette form) has a use within the HO screen
column18: or to free up some other item.  By the time you've completed the HO segment
column19: each object you found will have been used to a purpose
column20: to ultimately make the very last item available -- that's the one you keep.  In essence
column21: by emphasizing the use of found items for sequential problem-solving
column22: each HO segment is made into its own HO game in microcosm.  This works very well
column24: and makes the HO screens feel less pointless.  Of course
column25: the fact the these segments are done in isolation and cut you off from your regular inventory does lead to occasional yelling at the screen "I don't need that!  I already have a knife!" but it's still feels more meaningfully integrated with the game plot than a normal HO segment."

reviewText:
A well-balanced, fun, and quite long casual point-and-click adventure game. There are many low-difficulty puzzles and a handful of hidden-object scenes. I recommend playing in expert mode: adds a bit more challenge, and then you can also get an extra achievement.

The background story is poorly integrated into the game, but it's OK. It takes place in New York (it's in the title!) but you really wouldn't know: there's nothing about New York in the story or mood. The voice acting, as usual, is horrendous. You play a pretty lady detective: typical for the genre, and an obvious nod to the clientèle. Also typically the characters are quite meaningless. Who cares, just point and click and have a nice semi-thoughtful time few hours!

Try to find of all the collection objects on your own! Until you finish the game, you can revisit all the locations and continue searching. The in-game strategy game will show all the solutions if you're stuck. So, use the guide only when you get near the end and haven't found everything.

reviewText: One of the best Hidden Object Games, telling the story of a detective called to investigate the disappearance of a few mafia bosses and some children. Very well detailed, good puzzles and the hidden object scenes are interesting, not a mess of casual things but you need to find tools in a logical order to find the one that you're looking for to continue the story. Even the cutscenes are good enough and there's a bonus chapter after the main game with some backstory and other extras.

reviewText: They say an indication of proper game pricing is the length of game play to dollar ratio. For every dollar spent on the game there should be an hour of game time spent towards completing the game. In this case it is right on the money! Seven hours for seven dollars. Great game play, awesome story line, easy to navigate, and overall a very enjoyable game. 18/20 achievements earned on the first playthrough and I won't mind playing it again on a rainy day to pick up the other two I missed.

reviewText: Excellent game that, unlike most on the market, does take a while to complete. I completed it on Expert level. The puzzles are varied and challenging, the objects are fair but also challenging at times, and the story does the job to tie everything together. I would have thought with a game with 'The Mafia' in the title  may have been themed more towards that than what actually happens in the game but nevertheless it is still satisfying. In game help does feel a little like cheating if you use it but it's there if you need it. Overall, value for money and definately geared towards those with a bit of HOG experience under their belt.
